1.verse: This book records Moses’ address to the people of Israel when they were camped in the valley of the Arabah in the wilderness of Moab, east of the Jordan River. (Cities in the area included Suph, Paran, Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Dizahab.) The speech was given on February 15, forty years after the people of Israel left Mount Horeb—though it takes only eleven days to travel by foot from Mount Horeb to Kadesh-barnea,* going by way of Mount Seir! At the time of this address, King Sihon of the Amorites had already been defeated at Heshbon, and King Og of Bashan had been defeated at Ashtaroth, near Edrei. Here, then, is Moses’ address to Israel, stating all the laws God had commanded him to pass on to them:

5.verse: This book records Moses’ address to the people of Israel when they were camped in the valley of the Arabah in the wilderness of Moab, east of the Jordan River. (Cities in the area included Suph, Paran, Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth, and Dizahab.) The speech was given on February 15, forty years after the people of Israel left Mount Horeb—though it takes only eleven days to travel by foot from Mount Horeb to Kadesh-barnea,* going by way of Mount Seir! At the time of this address, King Sihon of the Amorites had already been defeated at Heshbon, and King Og of Bashan had been defeated at Ashtaroth, near Edrei. Here, then, is Moses’ address to Israel, stating all the laws God had commanded him to pass on to them:

6.verse: “It was forty years ago, at Mount Horeb, that Jehovah our God told us, ‘You have stayed here long enough.

7.verse: Now go and occupy the hill country of the Amorites, the valley of the Arabah, and the Negeb, and all the land of Canaan and Lebanon—the entire area from the shores of the Mediterranean Sea to the Euphrates River.

8.verse: I am giving all of it to you! Go in and possess it, for it is the land the Lord promised to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and all of their descendants.’

9.verse: “At that time I told the people, ‘I need help! You are a great burden for me to carry all by myself,

10.verse: for the Lord has multiplied you to become as many as the stars!

11.verse: And may he multiply you a thousand times more and bless you as he promised,

12.verse: but what can one man do to settle all your quarrels and problems?

13.verse: So choose some men from each tribe who are wise, experienced, and understanding, and I will appoint them as your leaders.’

14.verse: “They agreed to this;

15.verse: I took the men they selected, some from every tribe, and appointed them as administrative assistants in charge of thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens to decide their quarrels and assist them in every way.

16.verse: I instructed them to be perfectly fair at all times, even to foreigners.

17.verse: ‘When giving your decisions,’ I told them, ‘never favor a man because he is rich; be fair to great and small alike. Don’t fear their displeasure, for you are judging in the place of God. Bring me any cases too difficult for you, and I will handle them.’

18.verse: And I gave them other instructions at that time also.

19.verse: “Then we left Mount Horeb and traveled through the great and terrible desert, finally arriving among the Amorite hills to which the Lord our God had directed us. We were then at Kadesh-barnea on the border of the Promised Land and I said to the people, ‘The Lord God has given us this land. Go and possess it as he told us to. Don’t be afraid! Don’t even doubt!’

20.verse: “Then we left Mount Horeb and traveled through the great and terrible desert, finally arriving among the Amorite hills to which the Lord our God had directed us. We were then at Kadesh-barnea on the border of the Promised Land and I said to the people, ‘The Lord God has given us this land. Go and possess it as he told us to. Don’t be afraid! Don’t even doubt!’

21.verse: “Then we left Mount Horeb and traveled through the great and terrible desert, finally arriving among the Amorite hills to which the Lord our God had directed us. We were then at Kadesh-barnea on the border of the Promised Land and I said to the people, ‘The Lord God has given us this land. Go and possess it as he told us to. Don’t be afraid! Don’t even doubt!’

22.verse: “But they replied, ‘First let’s send out spies to discover the best route of entry, and to decide which cities we should capture first.’

23.verse: “This seemed like a good idea, so I chose twelve spies, one from each tribe.

24.verse: They crossed into the hills and came to the valley of Eshcol, and returned with samples of the local fruit. One look was enough to convince us that it was indeed a good land the Lord our God had given us.

25.verse: They crossed into the hills and came to the valley of Eshcol, and returned with samples of the local fruit. One look was enough to convince us that it was indeed a good land the Lord our God had given us.

26.verse: But the people refused to go in and rebelled against the Lord’s command.

27.verse: “They murmured and complained in their tents and said, ‘The Lord must hate us, bringing us here from Egypt to be slaughtered by these Amorites.

28.verse: What are we getting into? Our brothers who spied out the land have frightened us with their report. They say that the people of the land are tall and powerful, and that the walls of their cities rise high into the sky! They have even seen giants there—the descendants of the Anakim!’

29.verse: “But I said to them, ‘Don’t be afraid!

30.verse: The Lord God is your leader, and he will fight for you with his mighty miracles, just as you saw him do in Egypt.

31.verse: And you know how he has cared for you again and again here in the wilderness, just as a father cares for his child!’

32.verse: But nothing I said did any good. “They refused to believe the Lord our God

33.verse: who had led them all the way, and had selected the best places for them to camp, and had guided them by a pillar of fire at night and a pillar of cloud during the day.

34.verse: “Well, the Lord heard their complaining and was very angry. He vowed that not one person in that entire generation would live to see the good land he had promised their fathers,

35.verse: “Well, the Lord heard their complaining and was very angry. He vowed that not one person in that entire generation would live to see the good land he had promised their fathers,

36.verse: except Caleb (the son of Jephunneh), who, because he had wholly followed the Lord, would receive as his personal inheritance some of the land he had walked over.

37.verse: “And the Lord was even angry with me because of them and said to me, ‘You shall not enter the Promised Land!

38.verse: Instead, your assistant, Joshua (the son of Nun), shall lead the people. Encourage him as he prepares to take over the leadership.

39.verse: I will give the land to the children they said would die in the wilderness.

40.verse: But as for you of the older generation, turn around now and go on back across the desert toward the Red Sea.’

41.verse: “Then they confessed, ‘We have sinned! We will go into the land and fight for it as the Lord our God has told us to.’ So they strapped on their weapons and thought it would be easy to conquer the whole area.

42.verse: “But the Lord said to me, ‘Tell them not to do it, for I will not go with them; they will be struck down before their enemies.’

43.verse: “I told them, but they wouldn’t listen. Instead, they rebelled again against the Lord’s commandment and went on up into the hill country to fight.

44.verse: But the Amorites who lived there came out against them and chased them like bees and killed them from Seir to Hormah.

45.verse: Then they returned and wept before the Lord, but he wouldn’t listen.

46.verse: So they stayed there at Kadesh for a long time.

1.verse: “Then we turned back across the wilderness toward the Red Sea, for so the Lord had instructed me. For many years we wandered around in the area of Mount Seir.

2.verse: Then at last the Lord said,

3.verse: ‘You have stayed here long enough. Turn northward.

4.verse: Inform the people that they will be passing through the country belonging to their brothers the Edomites, the descendants of Esau who live in Seir; the Edomites will be nervous, so be careful.

5.verse: Don’t start a fight! For I have given them all the Mount Seir hill country as their permanent possession, and I will not give you even a tiny piece of their land.

6.verse: Pay them for whatever food or water you use.

7.verse: The Lord your God has watched over you and blessed you every step of the way for all these forty years as you have wandered around in this great wilderness; and you have lacked nothing in all that time.’

8.verse: “So we passed through Edom where our brothers lived, crossing the Arabah Road that goes south to Elath and Ezion-geber, and traveling northward toward the wilderness of Moab.

9.verse: “Then the Lord warned us, ‘Don’t attack the Moabites either, for I will not give you any of their land; I have given it to the descendants of Lot.’

10.verse: “(The Emim used to live in that area, a very large tribe, tall as the giants of Anakim;

11.verse: both the Emim and the Anakim are often referred to as the Rephaim, but the Moabites call them Emim.

12.verse: In earlier days the Horites lived in Seir, but they were driven out and displaced by the Edomites, the descendants of Esau, just as Israel would displace the peoples of Canaan, whose land had been assigned to Israel by the Lord.)

13.verse: “‘Now cross Zered Brook,’ the Lord said; and we did.

14.verse: “So it took us thirty-eight years to finally get across Zered Brook from Kadesh! For the Lord had decreed that this could not happen until all the men, who thirty-eight years earlier were old enough to bear arms, had died. Yes, the hand of the Lord was against them until finally all were dead.

15.verse: “So it took us thirty-eight years to finally get across Zered Brook from Kadesh! For the Lord had decreed that this could not happen until all the men, who thirty-eight years earlier were old enough to bear arms, had died. Yes, the hand of the Lord was against them until finally all were dead.

16.verse: “Then at last the Lord said to me,

17.verse: “Then at last the Lord said to me,

18.verse: ‘Today Israel shall cross the borders of Moab at Ar,

19.verse: into the land of the Ammonites. But do not attack them, for I will not give you any of their land. I have given it to the descendants of Lot.’

20.verse: “(That area, too, used to be inhabited by the Rephaim, called ‘Zamzummim’ by the Ammonites.

21.verse: They were a large and powerful tribe, as tall as the Anakim; but Jehovah destroyed them as the Ammonites came in, and the Ammonites lived there in their place.

22.verse: The Lord had similarly helped the descendants of Esau at Mount Seir, for he destroyed the Horites who were living there before them.

23.verse: Another similar situation occurred when the people of Caphtor invaded and destroyed the tribe of Avvim living in villages scattered across the countryside as far away as Gaza.)

24.verse: “Then the Lord said, ‘Cross the Arnon River into the land of King Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon. War against him and begin to take possession of his land.

25.verse: Beginning today I will make people throughout the whole earth tremble with fear because of you, and dread your arrival.’

26.verse: “Then from the wilderness of Kedemoth I sent ambassadors to King Sihon of Heshbon with a proposal of peace.

27.verse: ‘Let us pass through your land,’ we said. ‘We will stay on the main road and won’t turn off into the fields on either side.

28.verse: We will not steal food as we go, but will purchase every bite we eat and everything we drink; all we want is permission to pass through.

29.verse: The Edomites at Seir allowed us to go through their country, and so did the Moabites, whose capital is at Ar. We are on our way across the Jordan into the land the Lord our God has given us.’

30.verse: “But King Sihon refused because Jehovah your God made him obstinate, so that he could destroy Sihon by the hands of Israel, as has now been done.

31.verse: “Then the Lord said to me, ‘I have begun to give you the land of King Sihon; when you possess it, it shall belong to Israel forever.’

32.verse: “King Sihon then declared war on us and mobilized his forces at Jahaz.

33.verse: But the Lord our God crushed him, and we conquered all his cities and utterly destroyed everything, including the women and babies. We left nothing alive

34.verse: But the Lord our God crushed him, and we conquered all his cities and utterly destroyed everything, including the women and babies. We left nothing alive

35.verse: except the cattle, which we took as our reward, along with the booty gained from ransacking the cities we had taken. We conquered everything from Aroer to Gilead—from the edge of the Arnon River Valley, and including all the cities in the valley. Not one city was too strong for us, for the Lord our God gave all of them to us.

36.verse: except the cattle, which we took as our reward, along with the booty gained from ransacking the cities we had taken. We conquered everything from Aroer to Gilead—from the edge of the Arnon River Valley, and including all the cities in the valley. Not one city was too strong for us, for the Lord our God gave all of them to us.

37.verse: However, we stayed away from the people of Ammon and from the Jabbok River and the hill country cities, the places Jehovah our God had forbidden us to enter.

1.verse: “Next we turned toward King Og’s land of Bashan. He immediately mobilized his army and attacked us at Edrei. But the Lord told me not to be afraid of him. ‘All his people and his land are yours,’ the Lord told me. ‘You will do to him as you did to King Sihon of the Amorites at Heshbon.’

2.verse: “Next we turned toward King Og’s land of Bashan. He immediately mobilized his army and attacked us at Edrei. But the Lord told me not to be afraid of him. ‘All his people and his land are yours,’ the Lord told me. ‘You will do to him as you did to King Sihon of the Amorites at Heshbon.’

3.verse: So the Lord helped us fight against King Og and his people, and we killed them all.

4.verse: We conquered all sixty of his cities, the entire Argob region of Bashan.

5.verse: These were well-fortified cities with high walls and barred gates. Of course we also took all of the unwalled towns.

6.verse: We utterly destroyed the kingdom of Bashan just as we had destroyed King Sihon’s kingdom at Heshbon, killing the entire population—men, women, and children alike.

7.verse: But we kept the cattle and loot for ourselves.

8.verse: “We now possessed all the land of the two kings of the Amorites east of the Jordan River—all the land from the valley of the Arnon to Mount Hermon.

9.verse: (The Sidonians called Mount Hermon ‘Sirion,’ while the Amorites called it ‘Senir.’)

10.verse: We had now conquered all the cities on the plateau, and all of Gilead and Bashan as far as the cities of Salecah and Edrei.

11.verse: “Incidentally, King Og of Bashan was the last of the giant Rephaim. His iron bedstead is kept in a museum at Rabbah, one of the cities of the Ammonites, and measures thirteen and a half feet long by six feet wide.

12.verse: “At that time I gave the conquered land to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. To the tribes of Reuben and Gad I gave the area beginning at Aroer on the Arnon River, plus half of Mount Gilead, including its cities.

13.verse: The half-tribe of Manasseh received the remainder of Gilead and all of the former kingdom of King Og, the Argob region. (Bashan is sometimes called ‘The Land of the Rephaim.’)

14.verse: The clan of Jair, of the tribe of Manasseh, took over the whole Argob region (Bashan) to the borders of the Geshurites and Maacathites. They renamed their country after themselves, calling it Havvoth-jair (meaning ‘Jair’s Villages’) as it is still known today.

15.verse: Then I gave Gilead to the clan of Machir.

16.verse: The tribes of Reuben and Gad received the area extending from the Jabbok River in Gilead (which was the Ammonite frontier) to the middle of the valley of the Arnon River.

17.verse: They also received the Arabah (or wasteland), bounded by the Jordan River on the west, from Chinnereth to Mount Pisgah and the Dead Sea (also called the Sea of the Arabah).

18.verse: “At that time I reminded the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh that, although the Lord had given them the land, they could not begin settling down until their armed men led the other tribes across the Jordan to the land the Lord was giving them.

19.verse: “‘But your wives and children,’ I told them, ‘may live here in the cities the Lord has given you, caring for your many cattle

20.verse: until you return after the Lord has given victory to the other tribes too. When they conquer the land the Lord your God has given them across the Jordan River, then you may return here to your own land.’

21.verse: “Then I said to Joshua, ‘You have seen what the Lord your God has done to those two kings. You will do the same to all the kingdoms on the other side of the Jordan.

22.verse: Don’t be afraid of the nations there, for the Lord your God will fight for you.’

23.verse: “At that time I made this plea to God: ‘O Lord God, please let me cross over into the Promised Land—the good land beyond the Jordan River with its rolling hills—and Lebanon. I want to see the result of all the greatness and power you have been showing us; for what God in all of heaven or earth can do what you have done for us?’

24.verse: “At that time I made this plea to God: ‘O Lord God, please let me cross over into the Promised Land—the good land beyond the Jordan River with its rolling hills—and Lebanon. I want to see the result of all the greatness and power you have been showing us; for what God in all of heaven or earth can do what you have done for us?’

25.verse: “At that time I made this plea to God: ‘O Lord God, please let me cross over into the Promised Land—the good land beyond the Jordan River with its rolling hills—and Lebanon. I want to see the result of all the greatness and power you have been showing us; for what God in all of heaven or earth can do what you have done for us?’

26.verse: “But the Lord was angry with me because of you and would not let me cross over. ‘Speak of it no more,’ he ordered,

27.verse: ‘but go to the top of Mount Pisgah where you can look out in every direction, and there you will see the land in the distance. But you shall not cross the Jordan River.

28.verse: Commission Joshua to replace you, and then encourage him, for he shall lead the people across to conquer the land you will see from the mountaintop.’

29.verse: “So we remained in the valley near Beth-peor.

1.verse: “And now, O Israel, listen carefully to these laws I teach you, and obey them if you want to live and enter into and possess the land given you by the Lord God of your ancestors.

2.verse: Do not add other laws or subtract from these; just obey them, for they are from the Lord your God.

3.verse: You have seen what the Lord did to you at Baalpeor, where he destroyed many people for worshiping idols.

4.verse: But all of you who were faithful to the Lord your God are still alive today.

5.verse: “These are the laws for you to obey when you arrive in the land where you will live. They are from the Lord our God. He has given them to me to pass on to you.

6.verse: If you obey them, they will give you a reputation for wisdom and intelligence. When the surrounding nations hear these laws, they will exclaim, ‘What other nation is as wise and prudent as Israel!’

7.verse: For what other nation, great or small, has God among them, as the Lord our God is here among us whenever we call upon him?

8.verse: And what nation, no matter how great, has laws as fair as these I am giving you today?

9.verse: “But watch out! Be very careful never to forget what you have seen God doing for you. May his miracles have a deep and permanent effect upon your lives! Tell your children and your grandchildren about the glorious miracles he did.

10.verse: Tell them especially about the day you stood before the Lord at Mount Horeb, and he told me, ‘Summon the people before me and I will instruct them, so that they will learn always to reverence me, and so that they can teach my laws to their children.’

11.verse: You stood at the foot of the mountain, and the mountain burned with fire; flames shot far into the sky, surrounded by black clouds and deep darkness.

12.verse: And the Lord spoke to you from the fire; you heard his words but didn’t see him.

13.verse: He proclaimed the laws you must obey—the Ten Commandments—and wrote them on two stone tablets.

14.verse: Yes, it was at that time that the Lord commanded me to issue the laws you must obey when you arrive in the Promised Land.

15.verse: “But beware! You didn’t see the form of God that day as he spoke to you from the fire at Mount Horeb,

16.verse: so do not defile yourselves by trying to make a statue of God—an idol in any form, whether of a man, woman, animal, bird,

17.verse: so do not defile yourselves by trying to make a statue of God—an idol in any form, whether of a man, woman, animal, bird,

18.verse: a small animal that runs along the ground, or a fish.

19.verse: And do not look up into the sky to worship the sun, moon, or stars. The Lord may permit other nations to get away with this, but not you.

20.verse: The Lord has rescued you from prison—Egypt—to be his special people, his own inheritance; this is what you are today.

21.verse: But he was angry with me because of you; he vowed that I could not go over the Jordan River into the good land he has given you as your inheritance. I must die here on this side of the river.

22.verse: But he was angry with me because of you; he vowed that I could not go over the Jordan River into the good land he has given you as your inheritance. I must die here on this side of the river.

23.verse: Beware lest you break the contract the Lord your God has made with you! You will break it if you make any idols, for the Lord your God has utterly forbidden this.

24.verse: He is a devouring fire, a jealous God.

25.verse: “In the future, when your children and grandchildren are born and you have been in the land a long time, and you have defiled yourselves by making idols, and the Lord your God is very angry because of your sin,

26.verse: heaven and earth are witnesses that you shall be quickly destroyed from the land. Soon now you will cross the Jordan River and conquer that land. But your days there will be brief; you will then be utterly destroyed.

27.verse: For the Lord will scatter you among the nations, and you will be but few in number.

28.verse: There, far away, you will worship idols made from wood and stone, idols that neither see nor hear nor eat nor smell.

29.verse: “But you will also begin to search again for Jehovah your God, and you will find him when you search for him with all your heart and soul.

30.verse: When those bitter days have come upon you in the latter times, you will finally return to the Lord your God and listen to what he tells you.

31.verse: For the Lord your God is merciful—he will not abandon you nor destroy you nor forget the promises he has made to your ancestors.

32.verse: “In all history, going back to the time when God created man upon the earth, search from one end of the heavens to the other to see if you can find anything like this:

33.verse: An entire nation heard the voice of God speaking to it from fire, as you did, and lived!

34.verse: Where else will you ever find another example of God’s removing a nation from its slavery by sending terrible plagues, mighty miracles, war, and terror? Yet that is what the Lord your God did for you in Egypt, right before your very eyes.

35.verse: He did these things so you would realize that Jehovah is God, and that there is no one else like him.

36.verse: He let you hear his voice instructing you from heaven, and he let you see his great pillar of fire upon the earth; you even heard his words from the center of the fire.

37.verse: “It was because he loved your ancestors and chose to bless their descendants that he personally brought you out from Egypt with a great display of power.

38.verse: He drove away other nations greater by far than you and gave you their land as an inheritance, as it is today.

39.verse: This is your wonderful thought for the day: Jehovah is God both in heaven and down here upon the earth; and there is no God other than him!

40.verse: You must obey these laws that I will tell you today, so that all will be well with you and your children, and so that you will live forever in the land the Lord your God is giving you.”

41.verse: Then Moses instructed the people of Israel to set apart three cities east of the Jordan River,

42.verse: where anyone who accidentally killed someone could flee for safety.

43.verse: These cities were Bezer, on the plateau in the wilderness, for the tribe of Reuben; Ramoth, in Gilead, for the tribe of Gad; and Golan, in Bashan, for the tribe of Manasseh.

44.verse: Listed below are the laws Moses issued to the people of Israel when they left Egypt, and as they were camped east of the Jordan River near the city of Beth-peor. (This was the land formerly occupied by the Amorites under King Sihon, whose capital was Heshbon; he and his people were destroyed by Moses and the Israelis.

45.verse: Listed below are the laws Moses issued to the people of Israel when they left Egypt, and as they were camped east of the Jordan River near the city of Beth-peor. (This was the land formerly occupied by the Amorites under King Sihon, whose capital was Heshbon; he and his people were destroyed by Moses and the Israelis.

46.verse: Listed below are the laws Moses issued to the people of Israel when they left Egypt, and as they were camped east of the Jordan River near the city of Beth-peor. (This was the land formerly occupied by the Amorites under King Sihon, whose capital was Heshbon; he and his people were destroyed by Moses and the Israelis.

47.verse: Israel conquered his land and that of King Og of Bashan—they were two Amorite kings east of the Jordan.

48.verse: Israel also conquered all the area from Aroer at the edge of the Arnon River Valley to Mount Sirion, or Mount Hermon, as it is sometimes called;

49.verse: and all the Arabah east of the Jordan River over to the Dead Sea, below the slopes of Mount Pisgah.)

1.verse: Moses continued speaking to the people of Israel and said, “Listen carefully now to all these laws God has given you; learn them, and be sure to obey them!

2.verse: “The Lord our God made a contract with you at Mount Horeb—not with your ancestors, but with you who are here alive today.

3.verse: “The Lord our God made a contract with you at Mount Horeb—not with your ancestors, but with you who are here alive today.

4.verse: He spoke with you face to face from the center of the fire, there at the mountain.

5.verse: I stood as an intermediary between you and Jehovah, for you were afraid of the fire and did not go up to him on the mountain. He spoke to me and I passed on his laws to you. This is what he said:

6.verse: “‘I am Jehovah your God who rescued you from slavery in Egypt.

7.verse: “‘Never worship any god but me.

8.verse: “‘Never make idols; don’t worship images, whether of birds, animals, or fish.

9.verse: You shall not bow down to any images nor worship them in any way, for I am the Lord your God. I am a jealous God, and I will bring the curse of a father’s sins upon even the third and fourth generation of the children of those who hate me; but I will show kindness to a thousand generations of those who love me and keep my commandments.

10.verse: You shall not bow down to any images nor worship them in any way, for I am the Lord your God. I am a jealous God, and I will bring the curse of a father’s sins upon even the third and fourth generation of the children of those who hate me; but I will show kindness to a thousand generations of those who love me and keep my commandments.

11.verse: “‘You must never use my name to make a vow you don’t intend to keep. I will not overlook that.

12.verse: “‘Keep the Sabbath day holy. This is my command.

13.verse: Work the other six days,

14.verse: but the seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord your God; no work shall be done that day by you or by any of your household—your sons, daughters, servants, oxen, donkeys, or cattle; even foreigners living among you must obey this law. Everybody must rest as you do.

15.verse: Why should you keep the Sabbath? It is because you were slaves in Egypt, and the Lord your God brought you out with a great display of miracles.

16.verse: “‘Honor your father and mother (remember, this is a commandment of the Lord your God); if you do so, you shall have a long, prosperous life in the land he is giving you.

17.verse: “‘You must not murder.

18.verse: “‘You must not commit adultery.

19.verse: “‘You must not steal.

20.verse: “‘You must not tell lies.

21.verse: “‘You must not burn with desire for another man’s wife, nor envy him for his home, land, servants, oxen, donkeys, nor anything else he owns.’

22.verse: “The Lord has given these laws to each one of you from the heart of the fire, surrounded by the clouds and thick darkness that engulfed Mount Sinai. Those were the only commandments he gave you at that time, and he wrote them out on two stone tablets and gave them to me.

23.verse: But when you heard the loud voice from the darkness and saw the terrible fire at the top of the mountain, all your tribal leaders came to me

24.verse: and pleaded, ‘Today the Lord our God has shown us his glory and greatness; we have even heard his voice from the heart of the fire. Now we know that a man may speak to God and not die;

25.verse: but we will surely die if he speaks to us again. This awesome fire will consume us.

26.verse: What man can hear, as we have, the voice of the living God speaking from the heart of the fire, and live? You go and listen to all that God says, then come and tell us, and we will listen and obey.’

27.verse: What man can hear, as we have, the voice of the living God speaking from the heart of the fire, and live? You go and listen to all that God says, then come and tell us, and we will listen and obey.’

28.verse: “And the Lord agreed to your request and said to me, ‘I have heard what the people have said to you, and I agree.

29.verse: Oh, that they would always have such a heart for me, wanting to obey my commandments. Then all would go well with them in the future, and with their children throughout all generations!

30.verse: Go and tell them to return to their tents.

31.verse: Then you come back and stand here beside me, and I will give you all my commandments, and you shall teach them to the people; and they will obey them in the land I am giving to them.’”

32.verse: So Moses told the people, “You must obey all the commandments of the Lord your God, following his directions in every detail, going the whole way he has laid out for you;

33.verse: only then will you live long and prosperous lives in the land you are to enter and possess.

1.verse: “The Lord your God told me to give you all these commandments which you are to obey in the land you will soon be entering, where you will live.

2.verse: The purpose of these laws is to cause you, your sons, and your grandsons to reverence the Lord your God by obeying all of his instructions as long as you live; if you do, you will have long, prosperous years ahead of you.

3.verse: Therefore, O Israel, listen closely to each command and be careful to obey it, so that all will go well with you, and so that you will have many children. If you obey these commands, you will become a great nation in a glorious land ‘flowing with milk and honey,’ even as the God of your fathers promised you.

4.verse: “O Israel, listen: Jehovah is our God, Jehovah alone.

5.verse: You must love him with all your heart, soul, and might.

6.verse: And you must think constantly about these commandments I am giving you today.

7.verse: You must teach them to your children and talk about them when you are at home or out for a walk; at bedtime and the first thing in the morning.

8.verse: Tie them on your finger, wear them on your forehead,

9.verse: and write them on the doorposts of your house!

10.verse: “When the Lord your God has brought you into the land he promised your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and when he has given you great cities full of good things—cities you didn’t build, wells you didn’t dig, and vineyards and olive trees you didn’t plant—and when you have eaten until you can hold no more, then beware lest you forget the Lord who brought you out of the land of Egypt, the land of slavery.

11.verse: “When the Lord your God has brought you into the land he promised your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and when he has given you great cities full of good things—cities you didn’t build, wells you didn’t dig, and vineyards and olive trees you didn’t plant—and when you have eaten until you can hold no more, then beware lest you forget the Lord who brought you out of the land of Egypt, the land of slavery.

12.verse: “When the Lord your God has brought you into the land he promised your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and when he has given you great cities full of good things—cities you didn’t build, wells you didn’t dig, and vineyards and olive trees you didn’t plant—and when you have eaten until you can hold no more, then beware lest you forget the Lord who brought you out of the land of Egypt, the land of slavery.

13.verse: When you are full, don’t forget to be reverent to him and to serve him and to use his name alone to endorse your promises.

14.verse: “You must not worship the gods of the neighboring nations,

15.verse: for Jehovah your God who lives among you is a jealous God, and his anger may rise quickly against you, and wipe you off the face of the earth.

16.verse: You must not provoke him and try his patience as you did when you complained against him at Massah.

17.verse: You must actively obey him in everything he commands.

18.verse: Only then will you be doing what is right and good in the Lord’s eyes. If you obey him, all will go well for you, and you will be able to go in and possess the good land that the Lord promised your ancestors.

19.verse: You will also be able to throw out all the enemies living in your land, as the Lord agreed to help you do.

20.verse: “In the years to come when your son asks you, ‘What is the purpose of these laws which the Lord our God has given us?’

21.verse: you must tell him, ‘We were Pharaoh’s slaves in Egypt, and the Lord brought us out of Egypt with great power

22.verse: and mighty miracles—with terrible blows against Egypt and Pharaoh and all his people. We saw it all with our own eyes.

23.verse: He brought us out of Egypt so that he could give us this land he had promised to our ancestors.

24.verse: And he has commanded us to obey all of these laws and to reverence him so that he can preserve us alive as he has until now.

25.verse: For it always goes well with us when we obey all the laws of the Lord our God.’

1.verse: “When the Lord brings you into the Promised Land, as he soon will, he will destroy the following seven nations, all greater and mightier than you are: the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Amorites, the Canaanites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, the Jebusites.

2.verse: “When the Lord your God delivers them over to you to be destroyed, do a complete job of it—don’t make any treaties or show them mercy; utterly wipe them out.

3.verse: Do not intermarry with them, nor let your sons and daughters marry their sons and daughters.

4.verse: That would surely result in your young people’s beginning to worship their gods. Then the anger of the Lord would be hot against you, and he would surely destroy you.

5.verse: “You must break down the heathen altars and shatter the obelisks and cut up the shameful images and burn the idols.

6.verse: “For you are a holy people, dedicated to the Lord your God. He has chosen you from all the people on the face of the whole earth to be his own chosen ones.

7.verse: He didn’t choose you and pour out his love upon you because you were a larger nation than any other, for you were the smallest of all!

8.verse: It was just because he loves you, and because he kept his promise to your ancestors. That is why he brought you out of slavery in Egypt with such amazing power and mighty miracles.

9.verse: “Understand, therefore, that the Lord your God is the faithful God who for a thousand generations keeps his promises and constantly loves those who love him and who obey his commands.

10.verse: But those who hate him shall be punished publicly and destroyed. He will deal with them personally.

11.verse: Therefore, obey all these commandments I am giving you today.

12.verse: Because of your obedience, the Lord your God will keep his part of the contract which, in his tender love, he made with your fathers.

13.verse: And he will love you and bless you and make you into a great nation. He will make you fertile and give fertility to your ground and to your animals, so that you will have large crops of grain, grapes, and olives, and great flocks of cattle, sheep, and goats when you arrive in the land he promised your fathers to give you.

14.verse: You will be blessed above all the nations of the earth; not one of you, whether male or female, shall be barren, not even your cattle.

15.verse: And the Lord will take away all your sickness and will not let you suffer any of the diseases of Egypt you remember so well; he will give them all to your enemies!

16.verse: “You must destroy all the nations the Lord your God delivers into your hands. Have no pity, and do not worship their gods; if you do, it will be a sad day for you.

17.verse: Perhaps you will think to yourself, ‘How can we ever conquer these nations that are so much more powerful than we are?’

18.verse: But don’t be afraid of them! Just remember what the Lord your God did to Pharaoh and to all the land of Egypt.

19.verse: Do you remember the terrors the Lord sent upon them—your parents saw it with their own eyes—and the mighty miracles and wonders, and the power and strength of Almighty God that he used to bring you out of Egypt? Well, the Lord your God will use this same might against the people you fear.

20.verse: Moreover, the Lord your God will send hornets to drive out those who hide from you!

21.verse: “No, do not be afraid of those nations, for the Lord your God is among you, and he is a great and awesome God.

22.verse: He will cast them out a little at a time; he will not do it all at once, for if he did, the wild animals would multiply too quickly and become dangerous.

23.verse: He will do it gradually, and you will move in against those nations and destroy them.

24.verse: He will deliver their kings into your hands, and you will erase their names from the face of the earth. No one will be able to stand against you.

25.verse: “Burn their idols and do not touch the silver or gold they are made of. Do not take it or it will be a snare to you, for it is horrible to the Lord your God.

26.verse: Do not bring an idol into your home and worship it, for then your doom is sealed. Utterly detest it, for it is a cursed thing.

1.verse: “You must obey all the commandments I give you today. If you do, you will not only live, you will multiply and will go in and take over the land promised to your fathers by the Lord.

2.verse: Do you remember how the Lord led you through the wilderness for all those forty years, humbling you and testing you to find out how you would respond, and whether or not you would really obey him?

3.verse: Yes, he humbled you by letting you go hungry and then feeding you with manna, a food previously unknown to both you and your ancestors. He did it to help you realize that food isn’t everything, and that real life comes by obeying every command of God.

4.verse: For all these forty years your clothes haven’t grown old, and your feet haven’t been blistered or swollen.

5.verse: So you should realize that, as a man punishes his son, the Lord punishes you to help you.

6.verse: “Obey the laws of the Lord your God. Walk in his ways and fear him.

7.verse: For the Lord your God is bringing you into a good land of brooks, pools, gushing springs, valleys, and hills;

8.verse: it is a land of wheat and barley, of grapevines, fig trees, pomegranates, olives, and honey;

9.verse: it is a land where food is plentiful, and nothing is lacking; it is a land where iron is as common as stone, and copper is abundant in the hills.

10.verse: When you have eaten your fill, bless the Lord your God for the good land he has given you.

11.verse: “But that is the time to be careful! Beware that in your plenty you don’t forget the Lord your God and begin to disobey him.

12.verse: For when you have become full and prosperous and have built fine homes to live in, and when your flocks and herds have become very large, and your silver and gold have multiplied,

13.verse: For when you have become full and prosperous and have built fine homes to live in, and when your flocks and herds have become very large, and your silver and gold have multiplied,

14.verse: that is the time to watch out that you don’t become proud and forget the Lord your God who brought you out of your slavery in the land of Egypt.

15.verse: Beware that you don’t forget the God who led you through the great and terrible wilderness with the dangerous snakes and scorpions, where it was so hot and dry. He gave you water from the rock!

16.verse: He fed you with manna in the wilderness (it was a kind of bread unknown before) so that you would become humble and so that your trust in him would grow, and he could do you good.

17.verse: He did it so that you would never feel that it was your own power and might that made you wealthy.

18.verse: Always remember that it is the Lord your God who gives you power to become rich, and he does it to fulfill his promise to your ancestors.

19.verse: “But if you forget about the Lord your God and worship other gods instead, and follow evil ways, you shall certainly perish,

20.verse: just as the Lord has caused other nations in the past to perish. That will be your fate, too, if you don’t obey the Lord your God.

1.verse: “O Israel, listen! Today you are to cross the Jordan River and begin to dispossess the nations on the other side. Those nations are much greater and more powerful than you are! They live in high walled cities. Among them are the famed Anak giants, against whom none can stand!

2.verse: “O Israel, listen! Today you are to cross the Jordan River and begin to dispossess the nations on the other side. Those nations are much greater and more powerful than you are! They live in high walled cities. Among them are the famed Anak giants, against whom none can stand!

3.verse: But the Lord your God will go before you as a devouring fire to destroy them, so that you will quickly conquer them and drive them out.

4.verse: “Then, when the Lord has done this for you, don’t say to yourselves, ‘The Lord has helped us because we are so good!’ No, it is because of the wickedness of the other nations that he is doing it.

5.verse: It is not at all because you are such fine, upright people that the Lord will drive them out from before you! I say it again, it is only because of the wickedness of the other nations, and because of his promises to your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, that he will do it.

6.verse: I say it yet again: Jehovah your God is not giving you this good land because you are good, for you are not—you are a wicked, stubborn people.

7.verse: “Don’t you remember (oh, never forget it!) how continually angry you made the Lord your God out in the wilderness, from the day you left Egypt until now? For all this time you have constantly rebelled against him.

8.verse: “Don’t you remember how angry you made him at Mount Horeb? He was ready to destroy you.

9.verse: I was on the mountain at the time, receiving the contract which Jehovah had made with you—the stone tablets with the laws inscribed upon them. I was there for forty days and forty nights, and all that time I ate nothing. I didn’t even take a drink of water.

10.verse: At the end of those forty days and nights the Lord gave me the contract, the tablets on which he had written the commandments he had spoken from the fire-covered mountain while the people had watched below.

11.verse: At the end of those forty days and nights the Lord gave me the contract, the tablets on which he had written the commandments he had spoken from the fire-covered mountain while the people had watched below.

12.verse: He told me to go down quickly because the people I had led out of Egypt had defiled themselves, quickly turning away from the laws of God, and had made an idol from molten metal.

13.verse: “‘Let me alone that I may destroy this evil, stubborn people!’ the Lord told me, ‘and I will blot out their name from under heaven, and I will make a mighty nation of you, mightier and greater than they are.’

14.verse: “‘Let me alone that I may destroy this evil, stubborn people!’ the Lord told me, ‘and I will blot out their name from under heaven, and I will make a mighty nation of you, mightier and greater than they are.’

15.verse: “I came down from the burning mountain, holding in my hands the two tablets inscribed with the laws of God.

16.verse: There below me I could see the calf you had made in your terrible sin against the Lord your God. How quickly you turned away from him!

17.verse: I lifted the tablets high above my head and dashed them to the ground! I smashed them before your eyes!

18.verse: Then, for another forty days and nights I lay before the Lord, neither eating bread nor drinking water, for you had done what the Lord hated most, thus provoking him to great anger.

19.verse: How I feared for you—for the Lord was ready to destroy you. But that time, too, he listened to me.

20.verse: Aaron was in great danger because the Lord was so angry with him; but I prayed, and the Lord spared him.

21.verse: I took your sin—the calf you had made—and burned it and ground it into fine dust, and threw it into the stream that cascaded out of the mountain.

22.verse: “Again at Taberah and once again at Massah you angered the Lord, and yet again at Kibroth-hattaavah.

23.verse: At Kadesh-barnea, when the Lord told you to enter the land he had given you, you rebelled and wouldn’t believe that he would help you; you refused to obey him.

24.verse: Yes, you have been rebellious against the Lord from the first day I knew you.

25.verse: That is why I fell down before him for forty days and nights when the Lord was ready to destroy you.

26.verse: “I prayed to him, ‘O Lord God, don’t destroy your own people. They are your inheritance saved from Egypt by your mighty power and glorious strength.

27.verse: Don’t notice the rebellion and stubbornness of these people, but remember instead your promises to your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Oh, please overlook the awful wickedness and sin of these people.

28.verse: For if you destroy them, the Egyptians will say, “It is because the Lord wasn’t able to bring them to the land he promised them,” or “He destroyed them because he hated them: he brought them into the wilderness to slay them.”

29.verse: They are your people and your inheritance that you brought from Egypt by your great power and your mighty arm.’

1.verse: “At that time the Lord told me to cut two more stone tablets like the first ones, and to make a wooden Ark to keep them in, and to return to God on the mountain.

2.verse: He said he would rewrite on the tablets the same commandments that were on the tablets I had smashed, and that I should place them in the Ark.

3.verse: So I made an Ark of acacia wood and hewed out two stone tablets like the first two, and took the tablets up on the mountain to God.

4.verse: He again wrote the Ten Commandments on them and gave them to me. (They were the same commandments he had given you from the heart of the fire on the mountain as you all watched below.)

5.verse: Then I came down and placed the tablets in the Ark I had made, where they are to this day, just as the Lord commanded me.

6.verse: “The people of Israel then journeyed from Beeroth of Bene-jaakan to Moserah, where Aaron died and was buried. His son Eleazar became the next priest.

7.verse: “Then they journeyed to Gudgodah, and from there to Jotbathah, a land of brooks and water.

8.verse: It was there that Jehovah set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the Ark containing the Ten Commandments of Jehovah, and to stand before the Lord and to do his work and to bless his name, just as is done today.

9.verse: (That is why the tribe of Levi does not have a portion of land reserved for it in the Promised Land, as their brother tribes do; for as the Lord told them, he himself is their inheritance.)

10.verse: “As I said before, I stayed on the mountain before the Lord for forty days and nights the second time, just as I had the first, and the Lord again yielded to my pleas and didn’t destroy you.

11.verse: “But he said to me, ‘Arise and lead the people to the land I promised their fathers. It is time to go in and possess it.’

12.verse: “And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God require of you except to listen carefully to all he says to you, and to obey for your own good the commandments I am giving you today, and to love him, and to worship him with all your hearts and souls?

13.verse: “And now, Israel, what does the Lord your God require of you except to listen carefully to all he says to you, and to obey for your own good the commandments I am giving you today, and to love him, and to worship him with all your hearts and souls?

14.verse: Earth and highest heaven belong to the Lord your God.

15.verse: And yet he rejoiced in your fathers and loved them so much that he chose you, their children, to be above every other nation, as is evident today.

16.verse: Therefore, cleanse your sinful hearts and stop your stubbornness.

17.verse: “Jehovah your God is God of gods and Lord of lords. He is the great and mighty God, the God of terror who shows no partiality and takes no bribes.

18.verse: He gives justice to the fatherless and widows. He loves foreigners and gives them food and clothing.

19.verse: (You too must love foreigners, for you yourselves were foreigners in the land of Egypt.)

20.verse: You must fear the Lord your God and worship him and cling to him, and take oaths by his name alone.

21.verse: He is your praise and he is your God, the one who has done mighty miracles you yourselves have seen.

22.verse: When your ancestors went down into Egypt there were only seventy of them, but now the Lord your God has made you as many as the stars in the sky!

1.verse: “You must love the Lord your God and obey every one of his commands.

2.verse: Listen! I am not talking now to your children who have never experienced the Lord’s punishments or seen his greatness and his awesome power.

3.verse: They weren’t there to see the miracles he did in Egypt against Pharaoh and all his land.

4.verse: They didn’t see what God did to the armies of Egypt and to their horses and chariots—how he drowned them in the Red Sea as they were chasing you, and how the Lord has kept them powerless against you until this very day!

5.verse: They didn’t see how the Lord cared for you time and again through all the years you were wandering in the wilderness, until your arrival here.

6.verse: They weren’t there when Dathan and Abiram (the sons of Eliab, descendants of Reuben) sinned, and the earth opened up and swallowed them, with their households and tents and all their belongings, as all Israel watched!

7.verse: “But you have seen these mighty miracles!

8.verse: How carefully, then, you should obey these commandments I am going to give you today, so that you may have the strength to go in and possess the land you are about to enter.

9.verse: If you obey the commandments, you will have a long and good life in the land the Lord promised to your ancestors and to you, their descendants—a wonderful land ‘flowing with milk and honey’!

10.verse: For the land you are about to enter and possess is not like the land of Egypt where you have come from, where irrigation is necessary.

11.verse: It is a land of hills and valleys with plenty of rain—

12.verse: a land that the Lord your God personally cares for! His eyes are always upon it, day after day throughout the year!

13.verse: “And if you will carefully obey all of his commandments that I am going to give you today, and if you will love the Lord your God with all your hearts and souls and will worship him,

14.verse: then he will continue to send both the early and late rains that will produce wonderful crops of grain, grapes for your wine, and olive oil.

15.verse: He will give you lush pastureland for your cattle to graze in, and you yourselves shall have plenty to eat and be fully content.

16.verse: “But beware that your hearts do not turn from God to worship other gods.

17.verse: For if you do, the anger of the Lord will be hot against you, and he will shut the heavens—there will be no rain and no harvest, and you will quickly perish from the good land the Lord has given you.

18.verse: So keep these commandments carefully in mind. Tie them to your hand to remind you to obey them, and tie them to your forehead between your eyes!

19.verse: Teach them to your children. Talk about them when you are sitting at home, when you are out walking, at bedtime, and before breakfast!

20.verse: Write them upon the doors of your houses and upon your gates,

21.verse: so that as long as there is sky above the earth, you and your children will enjoy the good life awaiting you in the land the Lord has promised you.

22.verse: “If you carefully obey all the commandments I give you, loving the Lord your God, walking in all his ways, and clinging to him,

23.verse: then the Lord will drive out all the nations in your land, no matter how much greater and stronger than you they might be.

24.verse: Wherever you go, the land is yours. Your frontiers will stretch from the southern Negeb to Lebanon, and from the Euphrates River to the Mediterranean Sea.

25.verse: No one will be able to stand against you, for the Lord your God will send fear and dread ahead of you wherever you go, just as he has promised.

26.verse: “I am giving you the choice today between God’s blessing or God’s curse!

27.verse: There will be blessing if you obey the commandments of the Lord your God that I am giving you today,

28.verse: and a curse if you refuse them and worship the gods of these other nations.

29.verse: When the Lord your God brings you into the land to possess it, a blessing shall be proclaimed from Mount Gerizim and a curse from Mount Ebal!

30.verse: (Gerizim and Ebal are mountains west of the Jordan River, where the Canaanites live, in the wasteland near Gilgal, where the oaks of Moreh are.)

31.verse: For you are to cross the Jordan and live in the land the Lord is giving you.

32.verse: But you must obey all the laws I am giving you today.

1.verse: “These are the laws you must obey when you arrive in the land that Jehovah, the God of your fathers, has given you forever:

2.verse: “You must destroy all the heathen altars wherever you find them—high in the mountains, up in the hills, or under the trees.

3.verse: Break the altars, smash the obelisks, burn the shameful images, cut down the metal idols, and leave nothing even to remind you of them!

4.verse: “You must not make sacrifices to your God just anywhere, as the heathen sacrifice to their gods. Rather, you must build a sanctuary for him at a place he himself will select as his home.

5.verse: “You must not make sacrifices to your God just anywhere, as the heathen sacrifice to their gods. Rather, you must build a sanctuary for him at a place he himself will select as his home.

6.verse: There you shall bring to the Lord your burnt offerings and other sacrifices—your tithes, your offerings presented by the gesture of waving before the altar, your offerings to fulfill your vows, your freewill offerings, and your offerings of the firstborn animals of your flocks and herds.

7.verse: There you and your families shall feast before the Lord your God and shall rejoice in all he has done for you.

8.verse: “You will no longer go your own way as you do now, everyone doing whatever he thinks is right;

9.verse: (for these laws don’t go into effect until you arrive in the place of rest the Lord will give to you).

10.verse: But when you cross the Jordan River and live in the Promised Land, and the Lord gives you rest and keeps you safe from all your enemies,

11.verse: then you must bring all your burnt sacrifices and other offerings to his sanctuary, the place he will choose as his home.

12.verse: You shall rejoice there before the Lord with your sons and daughters and servants; and remember to invite the Levites to feast with you, for they have no land of their own.

13.verse: “You are not to sacrifice your burnt offerings just anywhere;

14.verse: you may only do so in the place the Lord will choose. He will pick a place in the territory allotted to one of the tribes. Only there may you offer your sacrifices and bring your offerings.

15.verse: However, the meat you eat may be butchered anywhere, just as you do now with gazelle and deer. Eat as much of this meat as you wish and as often as you are able to obtain it, because the Lord has prospered you. Those who are ceremonially defiled may eat it too.

16.verse: The only restriction is that you are not to eat the blood—pour it out on the ground, like water.

17.verse: “But none of the offerings may be eaten at home. Neither the tithe of your grain and new wine and olive oil, nor the firstborn of your flocks and herds, nor anything you have vowed to give the Lord, nor your freewill offerings, nor the offerings to be presented to the Lord by waving them before his altar.

18.verse: All these must be brought to the central altar where you, your children, and the Levites shall eat them before the Lord your God. He will tell you where this altar must be located. Rejoice before the Lord your God in everything you do.

19.verse: (By the way, be very careful not to forget about the Levites. Share with them.)

20.verse: “If, when the Lord enlarges your borders, the central altar is too far away from you, then your flocks and herds may be butchered on your own farms, just as you do now with gazelle and deer. And even persons who are ceremonially defiled may eat them. The only restriction is never to eat the blood, for the blood is the life, and you shall not eat the life with the meat.

21.verse: “If, when the Lord enlarges your borders, the central altar is too far away from you, then your flocks and herds may be butchered on your own farms, just as you do now with gazelle and deer. And even persons who are ceremonially defiled may eat them. The only restriction is never to eat the blood, for the blood is the life, and you shall not eat the life with the meat.

22.verse: “If, when the Lord enlarges your borders, the central altar is too far away from you, then your flocks and herds may be butchered on your own farms, just as you do now with gazelle and deer. And even persons who are ceremonially defiled may eat them. The only restriction is never to eat the blood, for the blood is the life, and you shall not eat the life with the meat.

23.verse: “If, when the Lord enlarges your borders, the central altar is too far away from you, then your flocks and herds may be butchered on your own farms, just as you do now with gazelle and deer. And even persons who are ceremonially defiled may eat them. The only restriction is never to eat the blood, for the blood is the life, and you shall not eat the life with the meat.

24.verse: Instead, pour the blood out upon the earth. If you do, all will be well with you and your children.

25.verse: Instead, pour the blood out upon the earth. If you do, all will be well with you and your children.

26.verse: Only your gifts to the Lord, and the offerings you have promised in your vows, and your burnt offerings need be taken to the central altar. These may only be sacrificed upon the altar of the Lord your God. The blood will be poured out upon the altar, and you will eat the meat.

27.verse: Only your gifts to the Lord, and the offerings you have promised in your vows, and your burnt offerings need be taken to the central altar. These may only be sacrificed upon the altar of the Lord your God. The blood will be poured out upon the altar, and you will eat the meat.

28.verse: “Be careful to obey all of these commandments. If you do what is right in the eyes of the Lord your God, all will go well with you and your children forever.

29.verse: When he destroys the nations in the land where you will live,

30.verse: don’t follow their example in worshiping their gods. Do not ask, ‘How do these nations worship their gods?’ and then go and worship as they do!

31.verse: You must not insult the Lord your God like that! These nations have done horrible things that he hates, all in the name of their religion. They have even roasted their sons and daughters in front of their gods.

32.verse: Obey all the commandments I give you. Do not add to or subtract from them.

1.verse: “If there is a prophet among you, or one who claims to foretell the future by dreams,

2.verse: and if his predictions come true but he says, ‘Come, let us worship the gods of the other nations,’

3.verse: don’t listen to him. For the Lord is testing you to find out whether or not you really love him with all your heart and soul.

4.verse: You must never worship any God but Jehovah; obey only his commands and cling to him.

5.verse: “The prophet who tries to lead you astray must be executed, for he has attempted to foment rebellion against the Lord your God who brought you out of slavery in the land of Egypt. By executing him you will clear out the evil from among you.

6.verse: “If your nearest relative or closest friend, even a brother, son, daughter, or beloved wife whispers to you to come and worship these foreign gods,

7.verse: “If your nearest relative or closest friend, even a brother, son, daughter, or beloved wife whispers to you to come and worship these foreign gods,

8.verse: do not consent or listen, and have no pity: Do not spare that person from the penalty; don’t conceal his horrible suggestion.

9.verse: Execute him! Your own hand shall be the first upon him to put him to death, then the hands of all the people.

10.verse: Stone him to death because he has tried to draw you away from the Lord your God who brought you from the land of Egypt, the place of slavery.

11.verse: Then all Israel will hear about his evil deed and will fear such wickedness as this among you.

12.verse: “If you ever hear it said about one of the cities of Israel that some worthless rabble have led their fellow citizens astray with the suggestion that they worship foreign gods, first check the facts to see if the rumor is true. If you find that it is, that it is certain that such a horrible thing is happening among you in one of the cities the Lord has given you,

13.verse: “If you ever hear it said about one of the cities of Israel that some worthless rabble have led their fellow citizens astray with the suggestion that they worship foreign gods, first check the facts to see if the rumor is true. If you find that it is, that it is certain that such a horrible thing is happening among you in one of the cities the Lord has given you,

14.verse: “If you ever hear it said about one of the cities of Israel that some worthless rabble have led their fellow citizens astray with the suggestion that they worship foreign gods, first check the facts to see if the rumor is true. If you find that it is, that it is certain that such a horrible thing is happening among you in one of the cities the Lord has given you,

15.verse: you must without fail declare war against that city and utterly destroy all of its inhabitants, and even all of the cattle.

16.verse: Afterwards you must pile all the booty into the middle of the street and burn it, then put the entire city to the torch, as a burnt offering to Jehovah your God. That city shall forever remain a lifeless mound and may never be rebuilt.

17.verse: Keep none of the booty! Then the Lord will turn from his fierce anger and be merciful to you, and have compassion upon you, and make you a great nation just as he promised your ancestors.

18.verse: “Of course, the Lord your God will be merciful only if you have been obedient to him and to his commandments that I am giving you today, and if you have been doing that which is right in the eyes of the Lord.

1.verse: “Since you are the people of God, never cut yourselves as the heathen do when they worship their idols nor shave the front halves of your heads for funerals.

2.verse: You belong exclusively to the Lord your God, and he has chosen you to be his own possession, more so than any other nation on the face of the earth.

3.verse: “You are not to eat any animal I have declared to be ceremonially defiled. These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat, the deer, the gazelle, the roebuck, the wild goat, the ibex, the antelope, and the mountain sheep.

4.verse: “You are not to eat any animal I have declared to be ceremonially defiled. These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat, the deer, the gazelle, the roebuck, the wild goat, the ibex, the antelope, and the mountain sheep.

5.verse: “You are not to eat any animal I have declared to be ceremonially defiled. These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat, the deer, the gazelle, the roebuck, the wild goat, the ibex, the antelope, and the mountain sheep.

6.verse: “Any animal that has cloven hooves and chews the cud may be eaten,

7.verse: but if the animal doesn’t have both, it may not be eaten. So you may not eat the camel, the hare, or the coney. They chew the cud but do not have cloven hooves.

8.verse: Pigs may not be eaten because, although they have cloven hooves, they don’t chew the cud. You may not even touch the dead bodies of such animals.

9.verse: “Only sea animals with fins and scales may be eaten;

10.verse: all other kinds are ceremonially defiled.

11.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

12.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

13.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

14.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

15.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

16.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

17.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

18.verse: “You may eat any bird except the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey, the buzzard, the falcon (any variety), the raven (any variety), the ostrich, the nighthawk, the sea gull, the hawk (any variety), the screech owl, the great owl, the horned owl, the pelican, the vulture, the cormorant, the stork, the heron (any variety), the hoopoe, the bat.

19.verse: “With certain exceptions, insects are a defilement to you and may not be eaten.

20.verse: “With certain exceptions, insects are a defilement to you and may not be eaten.

21.verse: “Don’t eat anything that has died a natural death. However, a foreigner among you may eat it. You may give it or sell it to him, but don’t eat it yourself, for you are holy to the Lord your God. “You must not boil a young goat in its mother’s milk.

22.verse: “You must tithe all of your crops every year.

23.verse: Bring this tithe to eat before the Lord your God at the place he shall choose as his sanctuary; this applies to your tithes of grain, new wine, olive oil, and the firstborn of your flocks and herds. The purpose of tithing is to teach you always to put God first in your lives.

24.verse: If the place the Lord chooses for his sanctuary is so far away that it isn’t convenient to carry your tithes to that place,

25.verse: then you may sell the tithe portion of your crops and herds and take the money to the Lord’s sanctuary.

26.verse: When you arrive, use the money to buy an ox, a sheep, some wine, or beer, to feast there before the Lord your God, and to rejoice with your household.

27.verse: “Don’t forget to share your income with the Levites in your community, for they have no property or crops as you do.

28.verse: “Every third year you are to use your entire tithe for local welfare programs:

29.verse: Give it to the Levites who have no inheritance among you, or to foreigners, or to widows and orphans within your city, so that they can eat and be satisfied; and then Jehovah your God will bless you and your work.

1.verse: “At the end of every seventh year there is to be a canceling of all debts!

2.verse: Every creditor shall write ‘Paid in full’ on any promissory note he holds against a fellow Israelite, for the Lord has released everyone from his obligation.

3.verse: (This release does not apply to foreigners.)

4.verse: No one will become poor because of this, for the Lord will greatly bless you in the land he is giving you if you obey this command. The only prerequisite for his blessing is that you carefully heed all the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today.

5.verse: No one will become poor because of this, for the Lord will greatly bless you in the land he is giving you if you obey this command. The only prerequisite for his blessing is that you carefully heed all the commands of the Lord your God that I am giving you today.

6.verse: He will bless you as he has promised. You shall lend money to many nations but will never need to borrow! You shall rule many nations, but they shall not rule over you!

7.verse: “But if, when you arrive in the land the Lord will give you, there are any among you who are poor, you must not shut your heart or hand against them;

8.verse: you must lend them as much as they need.

9.verse: Beware! Don’t refuse a loan because the year of debt cancellation is close at hand! If you refuse to make the loan and the needy man cries out to the Lord, it will be counted against you as a sin.

10.verse: You must lend him what he needs, and don’t moan about it either! For the Lord will prosper you in everything you do because of this!

11.verse: There will always be some among you who are poor; that is why this commandment is necessary. You must lend to them liberally.

12.verse: “If you buy a Hebrew slave, whether a man or woman, you must free him at the end of the sixth year you have owned him,

13.verse: and don’t send him away empty-handed!

14.verse: Give him a large farewell present from your flock, your olive press, and your winepress. Share with him in proportion as the Lord your God has blessed you.

15.verse: Remember that you were slaves in the land of Egypt and the Lord your God rescued you! That is why I am giving you this command.

16.verse: “But if your Hebrew slave doesn’t want to leave—if he says he loves you and enjoys your pleasant home and gets along well with you—

17.verse: then take an awl and pierce his ear into the door, and after that he shall be your slave forever. Do the same with your women slaves.

18.verse: But when you free a slave you must not feel bad, for remember that for six years he has cost you less than half the price of a hired hand! And the Lord your God will prosper all you do because you have released him!

19.verse: “You shall set aside for God all the firstborn males from your flocks and herds. Do not use the firstborn of your herds to work your fields, and do not shear the firstborn of your flocks of sheep and goats.

20.verse: Instead, you and your family shall eat these animals before the Lord your God each year at his sanctuary.

21.verse: However, if this firstborn animal has any defect such as being lame or blind, or if anything else is wrong with it, you shall not sacrifice it.

22.verse: Instead, use it for food for your family at home. Anyone, even if ceremonially defiled at the time, may eat it, just as anyone may eat a gazelle or deer.

23.verse: But don’t eat the blood; pour it out upon the ground like water.

1.verse: “Always remember to celebrate the Passover during the month of April, for that was when Jehovah your God brought you out of Egypt by night.

2.verse: Your Passover sacrifice shall be either a lamb or an ox, sacrificed to the Lord your God at his sanctuary.

3.verse: Eat the sacrifice with unleavened bread. Eat unleavened bread for seven days as a reminder of the bread you ate as you escaped from Egypt. This is to remind you that you left Egypt in such a hurry that there was no time for the bread to rise. Remember that day all the rest of your lives!

4.verse: For seven days no trace of yeast shall be in your homes, and none of the Passover lamb shall be left until the next morning.

5.verse: “The Passover is not to be eaten in your homes.

6.verse: It must be eaten at the place the Lord shall choose as his sanctuary. Sacrifice it there on the anniversary evening just as the sun goes down.

7.verse: Roast the lamb and eat it, then start back to your homes the next morning.

8.verse: For the following six days you shall eat no bread made with yeast. On the seventh day there shall be a quiet gathering of the people of each city before the Lord your God. Don’t do any work that day.

9.verse: “Seven weeks after the harvest begins,

10.verse: there shall be another festival before the Lord your God called the Festival of Weeks. At that time bring to him a freewill offering proportionate in size to his blessing upon you as judged by the amount of your harvest.

11.verse: It is a time to rejoice before the Lord with your family and household. And don’t forget to include the local Levites, foreigners, widows, and orphans. Invite them to accompany you to the celebration at the sanctuary.

12.verse: Remember! You were a slave in Egypt, so be sure to carry out this command.

13.verse: “Another celebration, the Festival of Shelters, must be observed for seven days at the end of the harvest season, after the grain is threshed and the grapes have been pressed.

14.verse: This will be a happy time of rejoicing together with your family and servants. And don’t forget to include the Levites, foreigners, orphans, and widows of your town.

15.verse: “This feast will be held at the sanctuary, which will be located at the place the Lord will designate. It is a time of deep thanksgiving to the Lord for blessing you with a good harvest and in so many other ways; it shall be a time of great joy.

16.verse: “Every man in Israel shall appear before the Lord your God three times a year at the sanctuary for these festivals: The Festival of Unleavened Bread, The Festival of Weeks, The Festival of Shelters. “On each of these occasions bring a gift to the Lord.

17.verse: Give as you are able, according as the Lord has blessed you.

18.verse: “Appoint judges and administrative officials for all the cities the Lord your God is giving you. They will administer justice in every part of the land.

19.verse: Never twist justice to benefit a rich man, and never accept bribes. For bribes blind the eyes of the wisest and corrupt their decisions.

20.verse: Justice must prevail. “That is the only way you will be successful in the land that the Lord your God is giving you.

21.verse: “Never, under any circumstances, are you to erect shameful images beside the altar of the Lord your God.

22.verse: And never set up stone pillars to worship them, for the Lord hates them!

1.verse: “Never sacrifice a sick or defective ox or sheep to the Lord your God. He doesn’t feel honored by such gifts!

2.verse: “If anyone, whether man or woman, in any village throughout your land violates your covenant with God by worshiping other gods, the sun, moon, or stars—which I have strictly forbidden—

3.verse: “If anyone, whether man or woman, in any village throughout your land violates your covenant with God by worshiping other gods, the sun, moon, or stars—which I have strictly forbidden—

4.verse: first check the rumor very carefully; if there is no doubt it is true,

5.verse: then that man or woman shall be taken outside the city and shall be stoned to death.

6.verse: However, never put a man to death on the testimony of only one witness; there must be at least two or three.

7.verse: The witnesses shall throw the first stones, and then all the people shall join in. In this way you will purge all evil from among you.

8.verse: “If a case arises that is too hard for you to decide—for instance, whether someone is guilty of murder when there is insufficient evidence, or whether someone’s rights have been violated—you shall take the case to the sanctuary of the Lord your God,

9.verse: to the priests and Levites, and the chief judge on duty at the time will make the decision.

10.verse: His decision is without appeal and is to be followed to the letter.

11.verse: The sentence he imposes is to be fully executed.
